awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide funding for the "Integers Conference 2018," which will be held in Augusta, Georgia, October 3-6, 2018. The conference is being hosted by the Department of Mathematics at Augusta University. The Integers conferences, of which this will be the eighth, serve to bring together mathematicians and students interested in the fields of combinatorics and number theory. It will promote interaction among research mathematicians at all career stages from the talented undergraduate to the internationally distinguished researcher. A large portion of the funding will support students, early-career faculty, and mathematicians belonging to underrepresented groups.
 
The conference will serve as a catalyst for major collaborative projects among mathematicians representing the areas of additive number theory, multiplicative number theory, combinatorial game theory, probabilistic number theory, enumerative combinatorics, combinatorial optimization, Ramsey theory, the theory of partitions, and other areas of combinatorics and number theory. It will feature three plenary speakers and around sixty additional speakers. The conference organizers plan to support twenty student research talks, including talks presented by students who have recently participated in an NSF "Research Experiences for Undergraduates" program. The proceedings of the conference will be published as a special volume of the journal Integers. The following website has been created for the conference:  https://sites.google.com/a/westga.edu/integersconference2018/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Integers Conference 2018 was held October 3 - 6, 2018 at the Augusta Marriott at the Convention Center in Augusta, Georgia.  The conferenced included three one-hour plenary talks as well as talks by several other distinguished number theorists. The plenary speakers were Fan Chung of the University of California at San Diego, Michael Filaseta of the University of South Carolina, and Paul Pollack of the University of Geogia. There were a total of seventy talks given, representing recent research advances in such areas of study as additive number theory, multiplicative number theory, the theory of partitions, combinatorics, combinatorial game theory, algebraic number theory, probabilistic number theory, and Ramsey theory. One of the main goals of the conference was to recruit graduate and undergraduate students and give them the opportunity to mingle with and learn from many accomplished researchers in the fields of number theory and combinatoriial theory. Fourteen of the speakers were students, including four undergraduate students. There were also a substantial number of talks given by early-career mathematicians.  In order to help disseminate the reseach results and ideas generated at the conference, all speakers were invited to submit articles based on their talks for a special volume of the journal Integers which will be titled "Proceedings of the Integers Conference 2018."  Seventeen articles were submitted for this volume, which we expect to be published in the early part of 2020.


Last Modified: 10/09/2019
Modified by: Bruce Landman
